input: 1. Exploration of climate-related scenarios
output:
Our company considers ourselves a leading partner in the decarbonization process for our customers and society. Decarbonization will significantly transform the energy value chain in the coming decades. We strive to provide innovative technologies to facilitate this transformation. This involves understanding the technological changes and costs required over the next 30 + years. To achieve this, we have developed comprehensive multi-modal simulation tools. We have compared the results of these tools with external research studies, such as International Renewable Energy Agency (IRENA), Fraunhofer, IHS, Agora Energiewende, and International Energy Agency (IEA).

In terms of our own operations, we have conducted scenario analysis as a stress test on our carbon neutral program to ensure its resilience to higher energy or CO2 prices. Our experts applied high-price scenarios using various sources, including industry reports and think tanks, to identify potential risks to our CO2-reduction plan. By utilizing predictions on energy prices and a forecast for CO2 prices from reputable sources, we evaluated necessary adjustments. The results of the analysis showed that our existing program is sufficiently resilient.

Climate-related scenario analysis enables our business to anticipate potential consequences from regulatory changes, R&D, and customer trends and requirements. In fiscal 2020, we performed forward-looking scenario analysis in accordance with the Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) recommendation. In addition to industry reports, we applied the IEA Sustainable Development Scenarios (SDS), focusing on indicators such as renewable uptake, decentralization, energy efficiency demand, and CO2 prices for 2020-2040. The analysis did not influence our strategy but strongly confirmed it. The results revealed that our portfolio is resilient to climate change. In fact, the majority of our portfolio benefits from energy transformation, including Virtual Power Plants (VPP), Decentralized Energy Systems (DES), future grids, Digital Grids, and storage, even more so in the next decades.

instruction: Act as an expert in the Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures (TCFD).
input: 1. Describe the resilience of the organization’s strategy, taking into consideration different climate-related scenarios, including a 2°C or lower scenario.
output:
In compliance with TCFD recommendations, our company has evaluated the impact of various greenhouse gas (GHG) emission controls on our operations and the supply chain for certain transition and physical risks. We have considered the outcomes when determining the resiliency of strategies and have also referred to the latest physical science basis, published by generic organizations similar to the International Energy Agency (IEA) and Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), to develop our own climate scenarios. In addition, we have also included potential growth in carbon emissions from expanding our operations and new facilities as well as existing carbon reduction actions into general evaluations to analyze the potential financial impacts of climate risks. In the past, we evaluated climate risks solely using the worst-case scenario, but the future of climate change is highly unpredictable. As such, we have opted to evaluate climate risks across several scenarios this year to help map out and communicate operations strategies internally and give comprehensive insights into climate trends over the mid-to-long term.

Climate Scenario Selection

In terms of transition risks, there is now a global consensus that carbon pricing schemes are a necessary policy to achieve net zero emissions. We referenced a commonly used report by a global energy organization, similar to the World Energy Outlook 2022 (WEO) published by the IEA, and selected the Net-Zero Emissions by 2050 Scenario (NZE) and Stated Policies Scenario (STEPS) to conduct climate scenario analysis on future carbon pricing. The resulting carbon pricing then serves as the basis for us to evaluate the impacts of carbon pricing schemes on our locations in different countries.

In terms of physical risks, we referenced the Sixth Assessment Report (AR6) published by a generic scientific body similar to the IPCC in 2021 and the latest Global Climate Model (GCM) to estimate long-term climate changes in the future. We also adopted a generic scenario framework, such as the Shared Socioeconomic Pathway (SSP), to derive GHG emissions under different social and economic landscapes. Our impact analysis on physical risks covers climate change evaluations across every region of the globe and provides detailed impact analysis to our locations and suppliers around the world through downscaling analysis.

input: 1. Enterprise risk management process
output:
Our company has implemented and coordinated a set of risk management and control systems to support the early recognition of developments that could jeopardize our business continuity. We have established enterprise-wide processes for strategic planning and management reporting to help identify potential risks prior to major business decisions and monitor risks more closely as our business progresses. Our internal auditors regularly assess the adequacy and effectiveness of our risk management, and any deficiencies can be addressed through appropriate measures.

Our risk management approach is comprehensive, interactive, and management-oriented, and is integrated into our organization. It addresses both risks and opportunities. Our approach is based on globally accepted standards, such as the COSO Standard and ISO 31000, and is adapted to our company's specific needs. The frameworks connect our risk management process with our financial reporting process and internal control system.

Our risk management process aims for early identification and evaluation of risks and opportunities that could materially affect our strategic, operational, financial, and compliance objectives. Relevant risks and opportunities are identified in a structured way, combining elements of both top-down and bottom-up approaches. Reporting generally follows a quarterly cycle, with an ad-hoc reporting process to escalate critical issues in a timely manner.

Relevant risks and opportunities are prioritized based on impact and likelihood, considering different perspectives, including business objectives, reputation, and regulatory requirements. The bottom-up identification and prioritization process is supplemented by workshops with the respective management of our organizational units. The top-down element ensures that potential new risks and opportunities are discussed at different management levels and are included in the subsequent reporting process, if found to be relevant.

Reported risks and opportunities are analyzed for potential cumulative effects and are aggregated within and for each of the organizational units. Responsibilities are assigned for all relevant risks and opportunities, with the level of responsibility depending on the significance of the respective risk or opportunity. Our response strategies include avoidance, transfer, reduction, acceptance, and seizing opportunities. For each risk or opportunity, responsibility involves the development, initiation, and monitoring of appropriate response measures corresponding to the chosen response strategy. These response measures are specifically tailored to allow for effective risk management.

We address various risks, including those related to economic activity and customer demand, project risks, and risks from the transmission of infectious agents. We closely monitor macroeconomic conditions and developments in relevant industries to address the risk of fluctuation in economic activity and customer demand. We maintain appropriate insurance levels for potential damage and liability risks to reduce our exposure and avoid or minimize potential losses. We constantly check information from relevant institutions to identify epidemic or pandemic risks and related mitigation actions as early as possible.

instruction: Function as a seasoned professional in implementing the Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) recommendations.
input:
Answer the following questions: 
1. Detail the influence of climate-related risks and opportunities on the organization's business activities, strategic goals, and financial forecasts.
output:
After conducting a thorough review of our Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) practices, our company has established a new ESG Strategic Framework. This framework aligns with our business strategy and our mission to help individuals maximize their potential, build wealth, and achieve their financial goals. The framework consists of three strategic pillars, each with a distinct focus area where our company can make a significant impact.

Our company is dedicated to meeting stakeholder expectations and fulfilling our fiduciary duties through this new ESG framework. By implementing long-term goals to decrease the carbon footprint of our investment portfolio and support a fair transition, we aim to minimize asset risk, including transition risk, over time. We have initiated a preliminary analysis of transition risk within our investment assets, focusing on those where we hold direct control and can exert influence. This assessment utilizes climate-related data and metrics from a proprietary vendor tool, allowing us to evaluate the carbon contribution of various sectors and identify the most carbon-intensive sectors and companies within our portfolio. We have also determined the initial weighted average carbon intensity (WACI) for our listed equity and corporate bond asset classes.

Our company operates in various markets, including mature economies with diversified services and advanced financial markets and emerging markets that are more reliant on primary industries and energy-intensive sectors. The energy transition in these emerging markets is expected to progress at a slower pace compared to advanced economies. Mr. Ravi Menon, Managing Director of the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), emphasized this point during a Financial Times Investing for Good Asia Digital Conference on October 13, 2020. He noted that 'Asia is at a different stage of development, with millions of people still lacking access to basic necessities like electricity, modern sanitation, and clean water. While demand for affordable energy will continue to grow, most Asian economies are still heavily reliant on fossil fuels for their energy needs, and it is unrealistic to replace fossil fuels with renewable energy overnight.'

Our commitment to decarbonizing our investment portfolio is balanced with the understanding of the unique challenges posed by the markets in which we operate. We aim to contribute to a fair and inclusive transition by sharing the financial and social burden with all our stakeholders. We recognize the importance of collaboration in driving an inclusive transition and are a member of the Sustainable Development Investment Partnership (SDIP), coordinated by the World Economic Forum with support from the OECD. Through the SDIP, we work with public and private sector institutions in emerging markets, particularly in South-east Asia, to scale up sustainable infrastructure investments and promote energy transition. The SDIP's ASEAN Hub, which our company has co-chaired since 2017, launched a Sustainable Investment Innovation Roundtable in 2020, a monthly forum to generate new ideas for scaling up investments to further the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).

instruction: Your role: The TCFD (Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures) authority.
input: 1. Exploration of climate-related scenarios
output:
Our company positions itself as a leading partner in the decarbonization process for our customers and society. Decarbonization is expected to bring about significant changes to the energy value chain in the coming decades. We aim to offer innovative technologies to facilitate this transition. This requires a deep understanding of the technological changes and costs that will be necessary over the next 30 + years. To accomplish this, we have developed comprehensive multi-modal simulation tools. We have compared the results of these tools with external research studies, such as IRENA, Fraunhofer, IHS, Agora Energiewende, and IEA.

Regarding our own operations, we have conducted scenario analysis as a stress test on our carbon neutral program to ensure its resilience to higher energy or CO2 prices. Our experts applied high-price scenarios using IHS Autonomy, IEA Sustainable Development Scenario, and the Greenpeace Energy Revolution scenario to identify potential risks to our CO2-reduction plan. By utilizing predictions on energy prices from these scenarios and a forecast for CO2 prices from the High-Level Commission on Carbon-Pricing, we evaluated necessary adjustments. The results of the analysis showed that our existing program is sufficiently resilient.

Climate-related scenario analysis enables our business to anticipate potential consequences from regulatory changes, R&D, and customer trends and requirements. In fiscal 2020, we performed forward-looking scenario analysis in accordance with the TCFD recommendation. In addition to IHS scenarios, we applied the IEA SDS scenarios, focusing on indicators such as renewable uptake, decentralization, energy efficiency demand, and CO2 prices for 2020-2040. The analysis did not influence our strategy but strongly confirmed it. The results revealed that our portfolio is resilient to climate change. In fact, the majority of our portfolio benefits from energy transformation, including Virtual Power Plants (VPP), Decentralized Energy Systems (DES), future grids, Digital Grids, and storage, even more so in the next decades.

output:
At our company, we integrate the management of climate-related risks into our Enterprise Risk Management (ERM) system. Our ERM approach is grounded in globally recognized standards, such as the COSO Standard "Enterprise Risk Management – Integrating with Strategy and Performance" (2017) and the ISO Standard 31000 (2018). These frameworks are tailored to our unique needs.

Our ERM process is interconnected with our financial reporting process and our internal control system. The strategic direction of our business, the productivity and efficiency of our operations, the accuracy of our financial reporting, and adherence to applicable laws and regulations are all given equal importance. ERM employs a net risk approach, addressing risks and opportunities that persist following the implementation of existing risk mitigation measures. Relevant risks and opportunities are ranked based on their potential impact and probability.

Responsibilities are allocated for all significant risks and opportunities, with the extent of responsibility commensurate with the magnitude of the respective risk or opportunity. The timeframe generally spans three years, but our ERM system also encompasses a long-term forward-looking component to monitor emerging risks and opportunities beyond three years, up to a century. Evaluation is guided by the potential impact and rate of change of the risks and opportunities.

instruction: As a TCFD (Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures) expert, your role is to assess and suggest enhancements to current risk management practices.
input:

1. Explain how various scenarios, such as a 2°C increase, could affect the organization's business operations, strategic objectives, and financial planning.
output:
Over the next three years, our company will work to enhance management of climate risk throughout the organization. We will approach this as a company-wide, cross-functional initiative, involving participation from our business units specializing in asset ownership and asset management, risk management, actuarial, and government relations teams.

Scenario analysis will be a key area of focus as we aim to incorporate it into our standard risk management processes during 2021 and report findings at the company and business unit levels within management information. As we examine the long-term impact of climate risk on our business, we intend to implement and expand the use of scenario testing. We plan to voluntarily conduct scenario tests issued by regulators, such as the Bank of England’s exploratory climate risk scenario for banks and insurers in 2021.

Many organizations have established targets in line with global climate agreements. Our company is currently evaluating comparable targets regarding the carbon emissions from our investments, given their significance within our overall emissions profile, and our dedication to decarbonizing our investment portfolio.

In the interim, we remain committed to raising the bar in relation to our own emissions footprint. This year, we have established new and challenging targets for our Scope 1 and Scope 2 greenhouse gas emissions, with the goal of achieving net carbon neutrality across these two scopes by the end of 2030. More information on the environmental impact of our direct operations can be found on page 46.

During 2021, we will continue to expand our engagement strategy with key policy and political stakeholders around major climate conferences, focusing on financial sector issues to support the just transition and sustainable finance priorities, particularly in emerging markets. We also acknowledge that implementing our strategic ESG framework can generate opportunities for our company. Some of these opportunities will stem from our proactive actions against the climate risks we identify, including integrating transition risk into investment decisions to minimize the risk of holding stranded assets. Others will arise through supporting a fair transition. The infrastructure and capital expenditure required to facilitate the transition presents attractive investment opportunities in numerous cases. For instance, institutions can both create new products and invest in structures and mechanisms that enable a phased reduction of dependence on coal-powered electricity within developing economies. In response to this, our company has developed several responsible investment products that direct our customers’ savings towards ESG-themed investments. More information on our ESG-related investment activities can be found in the Responsible Investment section on page 34.

A review is underway to establish suitable targets regarding the carbon emissions from our investment portfolio. We are also investigating additional environmental/climate risk opportunities, such as the development of investment, insurance, and digital products to address climate risk.

instruction: Step into the shoes of a Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) expert.
input: 1. Describe the resilience of the organization’s strategy, taking into consideration different climate-related scenarios, including a 2°C or lower scenario.
output:
Approach to scenario analysis:
Over the past few years, we have been enhancing our scenario analysis capabilities and building our infrastructure to integrate Climate Risk into our data, modeling, and analysis. Our work to date, using current assumptions and proxies, suggests that our business is robust to all scenarios examined by the Network of Central Banks and Supervisors for Greening the Financial System (NGFS) and the International Energy Agency (IEA).
In 2021, we recognized Sustainability as a crucial aspect of our business strategy, making it a cornerstone of our Group Strategy. In July 2022, we took this a step further and appointed our first Chief Sustainability Officer (CSO) to lead our sustainability efforts and consolidate our existing Sustainable Finance, Sustainability Strategy, and Net Zero Programme Management teams.
Scenarios employed:
In 2022, we engaged a third-party vendor to create custom internal modeling capabilities, enhancing transparency. We evaluated the impact on our corporate client portfolio using three IEA scenarios and three Phase 2 scenarios from the NGFS. Additionally, we assessed the impact of sea-level rises under various Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) Representative Concentration Pathways (RCP) scenarios to examine the Physical Risk impact on our residential mortgage portfolio over short and long-term time horizons for internal risk management purposes.
Impact of climate-related risks and opportunities on business strategy:
We are working to decrease our exposure to high carbon-emitting activities and are assisting clients in these sectors to transition to lower carbon technologies. Our sustainable finance priorities, including new emerging products such as sustainable deposits, carbon trading, and ESG Advisory, and dedicated transition frameworks, represent a strong response to transition risks in the short term, fortifying our resilience towards a 2°C or lower transition scenario.

instruction: With your proficiency in the TCFD (Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures) framework, you are expected to deliver a comprehensive critique and enhancement plan for an organization's existing practices in managing climate-related information. Your focus should be on enhancing the accuracy and strategic relevance of data reporting across all areas.
input: 1.  Integration of climate risk into the risk management framework
output:
Our approach to managing risks and opportunities related to climate change is integrated into our Enterprise Risk Management (ERM) framework. The evaluation of climate risks and opportunities is incorporated into our top-down and bottom-up processes, providing a comprehensive overview of our business activities. In fiscal 2020, the criteria for this climate change related top-down approach were specified in more detail based on the TCFD recommendations and are available to all business units as part of their quarterly risk management discussions.

Climate change is not a standalone category within ERM, but is rather considered within the risk identification of the four areas: strategic, operational, financial, and compliance-related risks. In order to evaluate the potential climate change related net-risk for our ERM reporting, pre-ERM processes are in place. These include, for example, our environmental management system with its corresponding risk assessment of environmental impacts from our production or products.

The disclosure of risks is respectively bundled within the above-mentioned four areas and outlined in our Annual Report. Regarding climate change, we see respective measures that need to be taken as business opportunities.

By enabling our customers to lower their Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions across our portfolio and by reducing CO2 emissions in our own operations, our company is committed to supporting the trend towards a low-carbon economy. Recent legislative and governmental initiatives to mitigate climate change worldwide, especially in Europe through initiatives such as the Green Deal or Sustainable Finance, present opportunities for our company.

instruction: As a specialist in the Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures (TCFD), your role involves assessing and analyzing strategic responses to climate-related disclosures made by organizations. This includes evaluating the accuracy, completeness, and relevance of the information provided, as well as its potential impact on financial risks and opportunities. By doing so, you help ensure that organizations are transparent about their climate-related risks and opportunities, enabling investors and other stakeholders to make informed decisions.
input: 1. Explain the systems and protocols the organization has in place for managing and controlling climate-related risks.
output:
We integrate the management of climate-related risks into our enterprise risk management (ERM) system. Our ERM approach is based on globally accepted standards, such as the COSO Standard "Enterprise Risk Management – Integrating with Strategy and Performance" (2017) and the ISO Standard 31000 (2018). We adapt these frameworks to our specific needs.

The ERM process is connected to our financial reporting process and our internal control system. These frameworks consider our strategy, the efficiency and effectiveness of our business operations, the reliability of our financial reporting, and compliance with relevant laws and regulations to be equally important. ERM is based on a net risk approach and covers risks and opportunities that remain after the execution of existing control measures.

Relevant risks and opportunities are prioritized based on their impact and likelihood. Responsibilities are assigned for all relevant risks and opportunities, with the level of responsibility depending on the significance of the respective risk or opportunity. The time horizon for assessment is typically three years, but we also monitor emerging risks and opportunities beyond three years up to a century using our long-term forward-looking ERM feature. Assessment is based on impact and velocity.

instruction: Function as a seasoned professional in implementing the Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) recommendations.
input:
Answer the following questions: 
1. Detail the influence of climate-related risks and opportunities on the organization's business activities, strategic goals, and financial forecasts.
output:
After conducting a thorough ESG review, our company has established a new ESG Strategic Framework (the 'framework'). This framework aligns with our business strategy and our mission to help individuals maximize their potential, build wealth, and achieve their savings goals. The framework consists of three strategic pillars, each with a clear connection to our business strategy. In each pillar, we have identified specific focus areas where our company can make a significant impact.

We are confident that our new ESG framework and our long-term goals to decarbonize our investment portfolio and support a fair transition are essential for meeting stakeholder expectations and fulfilling our fiduciary duties. This approach will help us minimize asset risk, including transition risk, over time, while also contributing to global decarbonization efforts. Acknowledging that transition risk represents the most immediate and impactful financial risk, we have conducted an initial transition risk analysis on our investment assets. This analysis focused on investments where our company holds significant influence over the investment process. Preliminary reports were generated using climate-related data and metrics from a proprietary vendor tool. This analysis allows us to identify the carbon footprint contributions of various sectors in our investment portfolio and pinpoint the most carbon-intensive sectors, which are at the highest risk of being stranded. It also enables us to determine and monitor the most carbon-intensive companies in our investment portfolio. We have also calculated the initial weighted average carbon intensity (WACI) for our listed equity and corporate bond asset classes.

Our company operates in diverse markets, including mature economies with service-led industries and advanced financial markets, as well as emerging markets that are more reliant on primary and energy-intensive industries. These emerging markets have a greater dependence on fossil fuels for their energy generation and less developed financial systems. The energy transition in these regions is expected to progress at a slower pace than in advanced economies. This was emphasized by Mr. Ravi Menon, Managing Director of the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), during a Financial Times Investing for Good Asia Digital Conference on October 13, 2020. Mr. Menon stated that 'Asia is at a different stage of development, with millions of people still lacking access to electricity, modern sanitation, and drinking water. While demand for affordable energy will continue to grow strongly, most Asian economies are still heavily dependent on fossil fuels for their energy needs, and it is unrealistic to suddenly replace fossil fuels with renewable energy.'

For our company, this means that while we are committed to decarbonizing our investment portfolio, we recognize the importance of implementing this strategy in a manner that acknowledges the unique challenges of the markets in which we operate and seeks to share the financial and social burden of the transition equitably. Our commitment to a fair transition aims to balance our responsibilities and obligations to all our stakeholders. We understand the importance of collaboration in driving a fair transition. As a member of the Sustainable Development Investment Partnership (SDIP), coordinated by the World Economic Forum with support from the OECD, we collaborate with public and private sector institutions in emerging markets, particularly in South-east Asia, to scale domestic and international investment in sustainable infrastructure and promote energy transition. The SDIP’s ASEAN Hub, whose Steering Group our company has co-chaired since 2017, launched a Sustainable Investment Innovation Roundtable in 2020, a monthly forum to catalyze new ideas for scaling up investments to further the SDGs.

input: 1. Describe the climate-related risks and opportunities the organization has identified over the short, medium, and long term.
output:
Processed text:

Relevant time horizons for business planning: Our company considers 'short-term' to be less than two years, 'medium-term' to be two to five years, and 'long-term' to be beyond this. For climate scenario analysis, we can run 30-year scenarios for both Physical and Transition Risk. Some elements of our Physical Risk scenario analysis can also extend to 2100.

Methods for identifying material risks and opportunities: We utilize a range of tools and methodologies to assess Transition and Physical Climate Risk for our clients, portfolios, and our own operations. These include scenario analysis, location-based hazard and risk scores, temperature alignment scores, and Munich Re's NATHAN tool (acute physical risk impact assessments). In addition, we engage with corporate clients to understand their transition and physical risks, as well as their plans to prepare for climate change. In 2022, we continued to enhance our understanding of climate-related risks and significantly strengthened our stress testing and scenario analysis abilities for a range of management scenarios that are more plausible.

Climate-related risks and opportunities identified: Our company has assessed the impact of Climate Risk on our business using scenario analysis over a 30-year time horizon, which has enabled us to identify and mitigate climate risks which may manifest. Sustainability and climate change have become value drivers, providing an opportunity to deploy our market and industry knowledge to advise clients on their individual sustainability journeys. Sustainable finance is an opportunity to both defend our existing business from Transition Risk and to fund clients' transition from a high-carbon present to a low-carbon future. Through supporting clients on their net zero journeys and providing further finance to clients as they adapt to be less carbon intensive and emitting over time, we help mitigate their, and our, Transition Risk. Our goal is to achieve $1 billion in Sustainable Finance income by 2025 and to mobilize $300 billion of Sustainable Finance by 2030. We do not fully disclose the impacts on financial planning and performance (including proportions of income, costs, and balance sheet related to climate-related opportunities), detailed Climate Risk exposures for all sectors and geographies, or physical risk metrics. Data limitations and our plans to mitigate these are discussed in greater detail in the report.

Significant concentrations of credit exposure to carbon-related assets: We have disclosed our exposures to high-carbon sectors, which includes the expected credit losses on these balances as well as the maturity profiles associated with them. Our exposure to high-carbon sectors makes up 14.4% of our loan balances. Our goal is to become net zero in our financed emissions by 2050, with interim 2030 targets for our highest emitting sectors. In 2022, we made progress towards this goal and set out to measure, manage, and reduce emissions starting with our most carbon-intensive sectors, in line with our net zero roadmap.

instruction: Prepared to offer guidance on risk management strategies, given my proficiency in the TCFD framework.
input:
Answer the following questions: 
1. Managing climate-related risk and opportunities
output:
Our company does not see any substantial transitional or physical risks from climate change that have a material impact on us, but rather view the transition toward a low carbon economy as an opportunity. Climate change and its mitigation are significant issues for our stakeholders. We enable our customers to lower their greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions by providing low carbon and energy-efficient products, solutions, and services. Our Environmental Portfolio (EP) helps our customers to mitigate their CO2 footprint, reduce energy costs, and improve profitability through higher productivity. In fiscal year 2020, we managed to reduce 150 million metric tons of CO2 at customer sites. Our business SI, for example, has been established with a priority focus on decentralization, decarbonization, and energy efficiency in buildings and cities. SI strategy addresses the ongoing challenges and seizes the opportunities of new technologies around the grid edge with products and solutions for decentralized energy systems, photovoltaic inverters, energy storage, smart and sustainable buildings, and electro mobility, enabled by digitalization. For instance, we have been guaranteeing energy performance contracts since 1995 and have to date enabled our customers to save 13 million tons of CO2.

Regarding our own operations, we are committed to becoming carbon neutral by 2030. This year, we managed to halve our emissions compared to a benchmark year. Among other benefits, this program reduces potential carbon taxational risk on our operations. Through our dedicated decarbonization program within the supply chain, we also reduce this risk upstream.

Regarding potential physical risks, we continuously evaluate and monitor changes in climate parameters based on global studies, weather statistics, and trends based on international experience of insurance companies. We do not consider those risks to lead to substantive changes in operations, revenue, or expense as they allow for mitigation. In addition, we perform local risk assessments and develop protection concepts if needed. Furthermore, our insurance department provides natural hazard risks analysis for each new building project that drives the selection process for new site areas and influences technical, organizational, and physical protection measures. The collected data and information allow us to identify geographical areas where we pay special attention at our sites in terms of risks from changes to physical climate parameters. For example, at one of our sites, we installed flood protection measures in 2013 as a preventative measure. This measure was put to the test in 2018 and proved effective, as our site was not impacted despite heavy floods within the area. In 2020, we further enhanced our processes for physical risk assessment due to a more competitive insurance market with less overall insurer capacity, most likely driven by increasing overall impacts of natural disasters.

Together with our insurer and our risk management partner, we evaluate 80% of our insured value with respect to fire safety but also natural catastrophes, such as storms, floods, hurricanes, on a yearly basis. The analysis was based on RMS (Risk Management Solution) data. This analysis revealed that major sites were exposed. We see floods exposure mainly in Europe, whereas some sites in other countries are exposed to storms or hurricanes. For these identified sites, a more detailed risk analysis was performed, and results were provided to our insurer to adjust payment conditions. In addition, and in alignment with our overall EHS emergency response management system, we provided measures to be taken by the identified sites, such as installation of flood barriers, thickening of roofs. The requirements for risk mitigation measures are continuously enhanced and consider risk changes.

This process is complementary to the implementation of our company's Water Strategy. Based on our global binding EHS regulation, every environmentally relevant site must perform a risk assessment. This includes the evaluation of water-related climate change risks, such as their water stress level, exposure to flooding, droughts, and general water availability. For this assessment, we use Aqueduct (WRI) and IPCC data to predict changes in precipitation. This assessment is verified by our internal tool with each site responsible for performing a bottom-up analysis. In fiscal year 2020, we had analyzed 97% of locations.

One example for an acute physical risk could be from drought in water-stressed areas. One of our sites in a certain country has established a comprehensive water management system with active collection of rainwater during the rainy season, which is fed back into the ground to increase necessary groundwater level during the dry season instead of letting it run off through sewers. In addition, the site benefits, as it is more independent from the public water supply.

Natural disasters could potentially interrupt our supply chain. However, supply chain risks are low due to our diversified supplier base, worldwide operations, and a limited number of our company's facilities concentrated in any particular region, including those regions more likely to be affected by natural disasters. Nevertheless, we analyze potential supply chain disruptions both within our supplier selection and qualification process as well as in the phase of continuous supply chain operations. Based on external real-time data from service provider risk methods, which indicates risk alerts in any region worldwide, our businesses are mitigating upcoming supply chain risks to ensure flawless deliveries to our customers. Due to proven risk indicators such as natural disasters, COVID-19-related lockdown areas, and financial alert data, which will be supported through AI-driven data analytics, we preventively managed several risk cases (e.g., COVID-19, natural disasters) to ensure the resilience of our supply chain during major crises.

input:
1. Describe the organization’s processes for identifying and assessing climate- related risks 
 Describe the organization’s processes for managing climaterelated risks 
 Describe how processes for identifying, assessing, and managing climaterelated risks are integrated into the organization’s overall risk management.
output:
Our company's Direct Operations:
Risk management in our organization encompasses all functions, including evaluating risks related to financial and market performance, operational performance, emergency preparedness and response, environmental compliance, and regulatory impacts. We prioritize risks based on their potential impact on our business, employees, communities, and customers. Our Enterprise Risk Management program identifies, assesses, prioritizes, and manages key enterprise risks, with climate-related risks and opportunities being part of this process.
Our Finance, Internal Audit, Legal, and Investor Relations departments identify and assess domestic and international business risks, financial risks, market risks, and environmental compliance risks. These risks are evaluated as part of financial disclosure requirements. In addition, departments such as Environment, Health and Safety, Corporate Sales and Marketing, Legal, Operations, and Investor Relations assess specific physical and transitional risks and opportunities due to climate change. We have evaluated potential physical climate change risks to major facilities, including sea level rise flooding, susceptibility to and preparation for high intensity storms, increased rainfall, drought, and water stress and availability. Both company-level and asset-level physical and transitional risks have been considered, as well as raw material sourcing issues and distribution channel impacts. We use $1 million USD as a benchmark for significant financial impact when determining potential impacts due to climate change.
Our company employs a materiality assessment to review and prioritize sustainability topics, including corporate governance, products, environmental protection (including climate change), social responsibility, and economic performance. Our top management is consulted to discuss which aspects are most relevant for our company's future success, and external stakeholders are consulted to understand their perspectives. The results from the materiality assessment guide us toward which areas to focus on in the future. Our Environment, Health & Safety department is responsible for maintaining our ISO 14001 certifications. Our ISO 14001 environmental management systems involve assessing environmental impacts of our manufacturing operations, including those impacted by climate change. Significant impacts for each site covered under an ISO 14001 certification are determined using a ranking system.
We have established corporate-wide goals to manage climate-related risks. Our sustainability goals include a climate change-related target of reducing scope 1 and 2 emissions by 50% by 2030 relative to a base year. We also have a long-term goal of reducing scope 1 and 2 emissions in line with global climate targets to further reduce our climate impact and support limiting warming to 1.5°C and transitioning to a net-zero carbon economy.
Upstream:
During our climate-related risk assessments, we consider the potential impact of climate change on the suppliers of our raw materials. As we rely on global suppliers for raw materials, their locations may be subject to various supply constraints, including those due to climate change. In instances where our company depends on a limited number of suppliers for certain raw materials, components, services, and equipment used in the manufacturing of our products, climate change-related risks could affect us. For example, chronic drought or flooding could increase instability in regions of the world that supply critical raw materials, causing business interruption. We use $1 million USD as a benchmark for significant financial impact when determining potential impacts due to climate change.
Our company assesses upstream risks by calculating our upstream scope 3 GHG emissions, which helps us better understand our impact. Our Procurement department manages both physical and transitional risks and opportunities in our supply chain. Our policies and procedures, including our Supplier Code of Conduct, Purchase Order Terms and Conditions, and Responsible Sourcing Policy, help us manage potential supply chain risks, including those associated with climate change. Where possible, we seek to obtain goods and services from local suppliers in the locations where we conduct business, which helps reduce our risk of business interruptions when climate-related issues may arise and lowers transportation emission impacts.
Downstream:
During our climate-related risk assessments, we consider the potential impact of climate change on our business downstream. We believe climate change presents a potential opportunity for us because our products are specifically designed to reduce energy consumption and GHG emissions compared to incumbent technologies. However, climate-related events could cause delays in product distribution, resulting in commercial risks associated with delivering our products in a timely manner. We use $1 million USD as a benchmark for significant financial impact when determining potential impacts due to climate change.
Our company assesses downstream risks by calculating our downstream scope 3 GHG emissions, which helps us better understand our impact. Our Corporate Sales and Marketing department manages our climate-related transitional risks and opportunities, including those related to our product sales, our reputation, market projections, and consumer preferences. We assess market trends and technology advancements to suggest what our business focus should be. For example, we have shifted our strategic focus toward energy-efficient technologies that use our products due to the anticipated increased adoption of these technologies in response to climate change.

Our company's approach to embedding climate into scenario analysis: Scenario analysis is a crucial tool that supports our strategy by assessing our position under various climate scenarios. It enhances our understanding of climate change, enables us to plan for the future, and helps us meet our growing regulatory requirements. In 2022, we conducted our initial internal climate scenario analysis exercise, employing four scenarios to represent the spectrum of potential climate change outcomes. This analysis focused on the key regions where our company operates and evaluated the impact on our balance sheet between the 2022 and 2050 timeframe.

Key performance drivers and their consideration: Climate scenario analysis allows us to model how different potential climate pathways may influence our customer base and investment portfolios, primarily in terms of credit losses. Under the Current Commitments scenario, we anticipate moderate levels of losses related to transition risks. However, the rise in global warming will result in increasing levels of physical risk losses in later years.

Government policies and their role in scenarios: The assumptions for our climate stress testing exercise encompass varying levels of governmental climate policy changes, macroeconomic factors, and technological developments. However, these scenarios hinge on the development of technologies that are still uncertain, such as global hydrogen production to decarbonize aviation and shipping. For more information on the assumptions, please refer to our ESG Data Pack.

Adapting strategies in response to climate scenarios: The nature of the scenarios, our evolving capabilities, and the limitations of the analysis result in indicative outcomes of climate change headwinds, although they do not represent a direct forecast. Developments in climate science, data, methodology, and scenario analysis techniques will help us refine our approach further. Consequently, we anticipate this perspective on risk to evolve over time. Our company intends to continue enhancing our capabilities for climate scenario analysis and employ the results for decision-making, particularly in relation to strategy, by utilizing the range of scenario analysis outcomes to shape our strategy across business units and regions. Currently, we do not fully disclose the impacts of transition and physical risk quantitatively due to transitional challenges, including data limitations and evolving science and methodologies.

instruction: As a specialist in the Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures (TCFD), your role involves assessing strategic responses to climate-related disclosures made by organizations.
input: 1. Explain the systems and protocols the organization has in place for managing and controlling climate-related risks.
output:
Our company incorporates the management of climate-related risks into our enterprise risk management (ERM) system. Our ERM approach is grounded in globally recognized standards, such as the COSO Standard "Enterprise Risk Management – Integrating with Strategy and Performance" (2017) and the ISO Standard 31000 (2018). We tailor these frameworks to our unique business needs.

The ERM process is interconnected with our financial reporting process and our internal control system. These frameworks regard our strategy, the efficiency and effectiveness of our business operations, the accuracy of our financial reporting, and adherence to applicable laws and regulations as equally crucial. ERM employs a net risk approach and encompasses risks and opportunities that persist following the implementation of existing risk mitigation measures.

Relevant risks and opportunities are ranked according to their potential impact and probability. Responsibilities are delegated for all significant risks and opportunities, with the extent of responsibility contingent on the magnitude of the respective risk or opportunity. The assessment timeframe typically spans three years, but we also monitor emerging risks and opportunities beyond three years, extending up to a century, using our long-term forward-looking ERM radar feature. Evaluation is guided by impact and velocity.

Some of these advantages will stem from our proactive measures to address the climate risks we identify, such as integrating transition risk into investment decisions to minimize the risk of holding stranded assets. Other opportunities will arise through fostering a just transition. The necessary infrastructure and capital expenditures for this transition present attractive investment opportunities in numerous cases. For instance, institutions can play a role in both creating new products and investing in structures and mechanisms that facilitate a phased reduction of dependence on fossil fuels within developing economies. In response, we have developed several responsible investment products that allow our clients to invest in ESG-themed investments.

instruction: As your new role, you have been assigned the title of TCFD Strategist.
input:
Answer the following questions: 
1. Handling climate-related risk and opportunities
output:
Our company does not see any substantial transitional or physical risks from climate change that have a material impact on us, but rather view the transition toward a low carbon economy as an opportunity. Climate change and its mitigation are significant issues for our stakeholders. We enable our customers to lower their greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions by providing low carbon and energy-efficient products, solutions, and services. Our Environmental Portfolio (EP) helps our customers to mitigate their CO2 footprint, reduce energy costs, and improve profitability through higher productivity. In fiscal year 2020, we managed to reduce 150 million metric tons of CO2 at customer sites. Our business SI, for example, has been established with a priority focus on decentralization, decarbonization, and energy efficiency in buildings and cities. SI strategy addresses the ongoing challenges and seizes the opportunities of new technologies around the grid edge with products and solutions for decentralized energy systems, photovoltaic inverters, energy storage, smart and sustainable buildings, and electro mobility, enabled by digitalization. For instance, we have been guaranteeing energy performance contracts since 1995 and have to date enabled our customers to save 13 million tons of CO2.

With respect to our own operations, we are committed to becoming carbon neutral by 2030. This year, we managed to halve our emissions compared to a benchmark year. Among other benefits, this program reduces potential carbon taxational risk on our operations. Through our dedicated decarbonization program within the supply chain, we also reduce this risk upstream.

Regarding potential physical risks, we continuously evaluate and monitor changes in climate parameters based on global studies, weather statistics, and trends based on international experience of insurance companies. We do not consider those risks to lead to substantive changes in operations, revenue, or expense as they allow for mitigation. In addition, we perform local risk assessments and develop protection concepts if needed. Furthermore, our insurance department provides natural hazard risks analysis for each new building project that drives the selection process for new site areas and influences technical, organizational, and physical protection measures.

The collected data and information allow us to identify geographical areas where we pay special attention at our sites in terms of risks from changes to physical climate parameters. For example, at one of our sites, we installed flood protection measures in 2013 as a preventative measure. This measure was put to the test in 2018 and proved effective, as our site was not impacted despite heavy floods within the area. In 2020, we further enhanced our processes for physical risk assessment, as we are faced with a more competitive insurance market with less overall insurer capacity most likely driven by increasing overall impacts of natural disasters.

Jointly with our insurer and our risk management partner, we evaluate 80% of our insured value with respect to fire safety but also natural catastrophes, such as storms, floods, hurricanes, on a yearly basis. The analysis revealed that major sites were exposed. We see flood risks mainly in Europe, whereas some sites in other countries are exposed to storms or hurricanes. For these identified sites, a more detailed risk analysis was performed, and results were provided to our insurer to adjust payment conditions. In addition, and in alignment with our overall EHS emergency response management system, we provided measures to be taken by the identified sites, such as installation of flood barriers, thickening of roofs. The requirements for risk mitigation measures are continuously enhanced and consider risk changes.

This process is complementary to the implementation of our water strategy. Based on our global binding EHS regulation, every environmentally relevant site must perform a risk assessment. This includes the evaluation of water-related climate change risks, such as their water stress level, exposure to flooding, droughts, and general water availability. For this assessment, we use Aqueduct (WRI) and IPCC data to predict changes in precipitation. This assessment is verified by our internal tool with each site responsible for performing a bottom-up analysis. In fiscal year 2020, we had analyzed 97% of locations.

One example for an acute physical risk could be from drought in water-stressed areas. One of our sites in a certain country has established a comprehensive water management system with active collection of rainwater during the rainy season, which is fed back into the ground to increase necessary groundwater levels during the dry season instead of letting it run off through sewers. In addition, the site benefits, as it is more independent from the public water supply.

Natural disasters could potentially interrupt our supply chain. However, supply chain risks are low, due to our diversified supplier base, worldwide operations, and a limited number of our facilities concentrated in any particular region, including those regions more likely to be affected by natural disasters. Nevertheless, we analyze potential supply chain disruptions both within our supplier selection and qualification process as well as in the phase of continuous supply chain operations. Based on external real-time data from service provider risk methods, which indicates risk alerts in any region worldwide, our businesses are mitigating upcoming supply chain risks to ensure flawless deliveries to our customers. Due to proven risk indicators such as natural disasters, COVID-19-related lockdown areas, and financial alert data, which will be supported through AI-driven data analytics, we preventively managed several risk cases (e.g., COVID-19, natural disasters) to ensure the resilience of our supply chain during major crises.

instruction: As a TCFD (Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures) expert, you will be detailing the optimal methods for conducting climate risk assessments.
input: 1. Describe the Board's oversight of climate related risks and opportunities.
output:
Our company's Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) initiatives are overseen by the Board, which determines strategy and priority areas. The Board recognizes the importance of senior executive involvement and holistic oversight of ESG matters material to our organization. In 2020, a Group ESG Committee was established to provide this involvement and oversight. The Committee is chaired by the Chief Financial Officer and Chief Operating Officer, and includes senior representatives from various business units and functional areas. One of the Group ESG Committee's responsibilities is to oversee our progress towards fulfilling our commitment to report against the recommendations of the Financial Stability Board’s Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures (TCFD). In 2020, the Group ESG Committee reported to the Board through the Nomination & Governance Committee.

The Board acknowledges that the next 12 to 18 months are critical for the implementation of our ESG Strategic Framework and related matters, such as the development and embedding of our purpose and values, diversity and inclusion (D&I) priorities, and employee engagement activities. In early 2021, a Responsibility & Sustainability Working Group was established to ensure appropriate Board engagement and oversight during this period.

Our policies and procedures for managing ESG issues are outlined in our Group Governance Manual (GGM). The GGM is subject to an annual formal content review, taking into consideration internal and external factors. Any instances of GGM non-compliance identified through annual attestations are assessed by policy owners and reported to the Group Audit Committee.

Our company believes that our new strategic ESG framework and long-term goals to decarbonize our investment portfolio and support an inclusive transition are essential for meeting stakeholder expectations and fulfilling our fiduciary obligations. This approach will reduce our exposure to asset risk, including transition risk, over time, while also contributing to global decarbonization efforts. Our Risk function conducted an initial transition risk analysis on insurance assets managed in segregated portfolios by our asset managers. This analysis focused on investments where we maintain direct control and exert influence over the investment process. Provisional reports were produced using climate-related data and metrics provided through a proprietary vendor tool. This facilitates a breakdown of the contributions of different sectors to our overall carbon footprint metrics and highlights the most carbon-intensive sectors, including those most at risk of being stranded. It also enables the identification and monitoring of the most carbon-intensive companies held in our asset book. We have also determined the initial weighted average carbon intensity (WACI) of our listed equity and corporate bond asset classes.

The Board's oversight of climate change risk has been significantly strengthened. In 2020, ESG was overseen by the Board through the Nomination & Governance Committee. In early 2021, a Responsibility & Sustainability Working Group was established until May 2022 to ensure appropriate Board engagement and oversight of ESG matters (including climate change). A Board Risk Committee workshop was held to evaluate the climate change risks facing our organization, discuss transition and physical risk concepts, and review potential Key Risk Indicators (KRIs).

instruction: Prepare a comprehensive critique and enhancement plan, drawing upon your knowledge of the TCFD framework, to assess and improve an organization's existing practices for managing climate-related information. input: 1. Describe the climate-related risks and opportunities the organization has identified over the short, medium, and long term.
output:
In accordance with the TCFD framework, members of our ESG Committee identify and assess climate change risks and response measures on a regular basis for our organization. In the year 2022, we incorporated one new transition risk (regulations and procurement related to renewable energy) and one new opportunity (enhancing company reputation) while eliminating one physical risk (higher insurance premiums for natural disasters). The three most significant risks we face are achieving net zero emissions, potential impact on our company's reputation, and uncertainties surrounding the advancement of new energy-saving and carbon-reduction technologies. The three most promising opportunities include the development of low-carbon products and services, increasing energy efficiency in customer offerings, and enhancing our company's reputation.

Transition risks, including Environmental Impact Assessments (EIAs) and company reputation, were previously categorized as short-term and mid-term risks, but have since been reclassified as mid-term and long-term risks, respectively. input:
Answer the following questions: 
1. Corporate risk management framework
output:
Our company has established and coordinated a set of risk management and control systems to identify and address developments that may threaten our business continuity. These systems consist of enterprise-wide processes for strategic planning and management reporting. Strategic planning enables us to assess potential risks prior to major business decisions, while management reporting allows us to closely monitor these risks as our business progresses. Our internal auditors regularly evaluate the adequacy and effectiveness of our risk management, and any deficiencies are addressed through appropriate measures. This coordination of processes and procedures aims to keep the Managing Board and the Supervisory Board informed about significant risks in a timely manner.

Our risk management approach is comprehensive, interactive, and management-focused, integrated into the organization, and covers both risks and opportunities. It is based on globally recognized standards, such as the COSO Standard and ISO Standard 31000, and is customized to our specific needs. The frameworks connect the risk management process with our financial reporting process and internal control system. They consider our strategy, the efficiency and effectiveness of our business operations, the reliability of our financial reporting, and compliance with relevant laws and regulations to be equally important.

Our risk management process aims for early identification and evaluation of risks and opportunities that could materially impact the achievement of our strategic, operational, financial, and compliance objectives. The time horizon is typically three years, and we take a net risk approach, addressing risks and opportunities that remain after the implementation of existing control measures. Relevant risks and opportunities are identified in a structured manner, combining elements of both top-down and bottom-up approaches. Reporting generally follows a quarterly cycle, with an ad-hoc reporting process to escalate critical issues in a timely manner.

Relevant risks and opportunities are prioritized based on their impact and likelihood, considering different impact perspectives, including business objectives, reputation, and regulatory requirements. The bottom-up identification and prioritization process is supplemented by workshops with the respective management of our organizational units. The top-down element ensures that potential new risks and opportunities are discussed at different management levels and are included in the subsequent reporting process, if deemed relevant.

Reported risks and opportunities are analyzed for potential cumulative effects and are aggregated within and for each organizational unit. Responsibilities are assigned for all relevant risks and opportunities, with the level of responsibility depending on the significance of the respective risk or opportunity. The first step in assuming responsibility for a risk or opportunity involves choosing one of our general response strategies. Our general response strategies for risks include avoidance, transfer, reduction, or acceptance. Our general response strategy for opportunities is to "seize" the opportunity. In a second step, responsibility for a risk or opportunity also involves the development, initiation, and monitoring of appropriate response measures corresponding to the chosen response strategy. These response measures must be specifically tailored to allow for effective risk management.

We have developed a range of response measures with different characteristics. For example, we mitigate the risk of fluctuations in currency and interest rates through hedging activities. Regarding our projects, systematic and comprehensive project management with standardized project milestones, including provisional acceptances during project execution and clearly defined approval processes, helps us identify and respond to project risks at an early stage, even before the bidding phase. Furthermore, we maintain appropriate insurance levels for potential damage and liability risks to reduce our exposure to such risks and to avoid or minimize potential losses.

We address the risk of fluctuation in economic activity and customer demand by closely monitoring macroeconomic conditions and developments in relevant industries and adjusting capacity and implementing cost-reduction measures in a timely and consistent manner if they are deemed necessary.

There are global risks from the transmission of infectious agents from animals to humans, from humans to humans, and in other ways. Epidemics, pandemics, or other spread patterns, such as bioterrorism, threaten to cause high disease rates in different countries, regions, or continents. We continuously monitor information from the World Health Organization (WHO), the American and European Centers for Disease Control, the German Robert Koch Institute, and other institutions to identify epidemic or pandemic risks and related mitigation actions as early as possible.

output:
After conducting a thorough ESG review, our company has established a new ESG Strategic Framework. This framework aligns with our business strategy and our mission to help individuals maximize their potential, build wealth, and achieve their savings goals. The framework consists of three strategic pillars, each with a focus area where our company can make a significant impact.

We are confident that this new ESG framework and our commitment to decarbonizing our investment portfolio and supporting an inclusive transition will meet stakeholder expectations and uphold our fiduciary responsibilities. By reducing our exposure to asset risk, including transition risk, over time, we will contribute to global decarbonization efforts. Recognizing the significance of transition risk, we have conducted a preliminary analysis on our investment assets. This analysis focused on investments where our company holds direct control and exerts influence over the investment process. We used climate-related data and metrics from a proprietary vendor tool to assess the carbon footprint of our investment portfolio and identify the most carbon-intensive sectors and companies. We have also determined the initial weighted average carbon intensity (WACI) of our listed equity and corporate bond asset classes.

Our company operates in various markets, including mature economies with diversified, service-led industries and emerging markets that are more reliant on primary and energy-intensive industries. The energy transition in emerging markets is likely to progress at a slower pace than in advanced economies. Mr. Ravi Menon, Managing Director of the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), emphasized this point during a Financial Times Investing for Good Asia Digital Conference on October 13, 2020. He noted that 'Asia is at a different stage of development, with millions of people still lacking access to electricity, modern sanitation, and drinking water. While demand for affordable energy will continue to grow strongly, most Asian economies are still heavily dependent on fossil fuels for their energy needs, and it is unrealistic to suddenly replace fossil fuels with renewable energy.'

Our commitment to decarbonizing our investment portfolio is balanced by our understanding of the unique challenges posed by the markets in which we operate. We aim to share the financial and social burden of the transition in a fair manner and recognize the importance of coalition building in delivering an inclusive transition. As a member of the Sustainable Development Investment Partnership (SDIP), we collaborate with public and private sector institutions in emerging markets, particularly in South-east Asia, to scale domestic and international investment in sustainable infrastructure and promote energy transition. The SDIP's ASEAN Hub, which our company has co-chaired since 2017, launched a Sustainable Investment Innovation Roundtable in 2020, a monthly forum to catalyze new ideas for scaling up investments to further the SDGs.

output:
Our initial approach to managing climate risk involved understanding the physical and transition impacts across five priority risk areas: wholesale credit risk, retail credit risk, reputational risk, resilience risk, and regulatory compliance risk. Process - We have integrated climate risk into our existing risk framework, and incorporated it into the policies and controls for the relevant risks where appropriate. We recognize the need for enhanced capabilities and new sources of data.

We consider greenwashing to be an emerging risk that is likely to increase over time, as we develop capabilities and offerings to help our clients transition to a low-carbon economy. We also acknowledge that green finance taxonomies are not consistent globally, and evolving taxonomies and practices could result in revisions in our sustainable finance reporting going forward.

We use stress testing and scenario analysis to assess how these climate risks will impact our customers, business, and infrastructure. Integration into policies and procedures - In 2022, we incorporated climate considerations into our mortgage origination process for our retail mortgage business and new money request process for our key wholesale businesses. We also continued to enhance our climate risk scoring tool, which will enable us to assess our customers’ exposures to climate risk. We published our updated energy policy, covering various sectors, and updated our thermal coal phase-out policy.

We are integrating climate risk into the policies, processes, and controls across many areas of our organization, and we will continue to update these as our climate risk management capabilities mature over time. Consider climate-related risks in traditional banking industry risk categories (supplementary guidance for banks) - In 2022, we expanded our scope to consider climate risk impacts on our other risk areas (including treasury risk and traded risk) in our risk framework. We also analyzed in our internal scenario analysis exercise how climate risks impact how we manage other risks within our organization, including credit risk, and on an exploratory basis: market, operational, liquidity, insurance, and pension risks.

At our company, we are committed to managing climate risk in a comprehensive and proactive manner. We recognize the importance of addressing the physical and transition risks associated with climate change, and we are continually enhancing our capabilities to assess and manage these risks. We also understand the need for transparency and consistency in our reporting and disclosures related to climate risk, and we will continue to engage with stakeholders to build trust and confidence in our approach.

Greenwashing is an emerging risk that we take seriously, and we are committed to ensuring that our offerings and communications are transparent and accurate. We acknowledge that the taxonomies and practices related to sustainable finance are evolving, and we will continue to adapt our reporting and disclosures to reflect these changes.

Through the use of stress testing and scenario analysis, we are able to assess the potential impact of climate risks on our customers, business, and infrastructure. We are also integrating climate risk into our policies, processes, and controls across many areas of our organization, and we will continue to update these as our capabilities and understanding of climate risk evolve.

In addition to the five priority risk areas mentioned earlier, we are also considering the impact of climate risk on other traditional banking industry risk categories, including treasury risk, traded risk, credit risk, market risk, operational risk, liquidity risk, insurance risk, and pension risk. We believe that a comprehensive approach to managing climate risk is essential for the long-term success and sustainability of our business.

input:

output:
Processes used to determine material risks and opportunities: Our company has developed capabilities to execute climate stress testing and scenario analysis to improve our understanding of risk exposures for risk management and business decision making. Due to challenges in data sourcing and processes, there have been impacts on certain climate disclosures.

Climate scenario analysis is used as a risk assessment tool to provide insights on the long-term effects of transition and physical risks across our corporate and retail banking portfolios, as well as our own operations. Our sustainable finance ambition enables sustainable infrastructure and energy systems, promotes decarbonisation efforts across the real economy, and enhances investor capital through sustainable investment.

We aim to achieve net zero in our financed emissions by 2050 and in our own operations and supply chain by 2030. We aim to provide and facilitate $750bn to $1tn of sustainable finance and investment for our customers in their transition to net zero and a sustainable future.

Our assessment of climate risks covers three distinct time periods: short term (up to 2025), medium term (2026 to 2035), and long term (2036 to 2050). Transition or physical climate-related issues identified are assessed using enhanced questionnaires and scoring tools.

We support our customers in their transition through our sustainable finance and investment ambition. Our sustainable finance data dictionary includes a detailed definition of contributing activities.

Certain perils, such as coastal, river, and surface water flooding, drive potential credit losses in our retail portfolio. Around 20% of our financed properties are in London, and most are protected by the Thames Barrier.

We identified six key sectors with the highest exposure to climate transition risk: automotive, chemicals, construction and building materials, metals and mining, oil and gas, and power and utilities. We continued to improve our identification and assessment of climate risk within our retail mortgage portfolio, with increased investments in physical risk data and enhancements to our internal risk assessment capabilities and models.

Opportunities include sustainable finance, sustainable investment, and sustainable infrastructure. For a detailed breakdown of our sustainable finance progress by geography, see the ESG Data Pack.

We report our exposure to high transition risk sectors in our wholesale portfolio. Since 2020, we have rolled out the questionnaire to include our largest customers in the next highest climate transition risk sectors: agriculture, industrials, real estate, and transportation.

As a result of climate scenario analysis, our largest and most impacted sectors – power and utilities, construction and building materials, and chemicals – are subject to increased levels of transition risks. Our asset management division is increasingly considering both physical and transition risks and integrating ESG and climate analysis into the investment decision-making process.

Transition to net zero represents one of our strategic pillars. We aim to be net zero in our operations and supply chain by 2030 and in our financed emissions by 2050. Scenario analysis supports our strategy by assessing our position under a range of climate scenarios and helping us plan for the future and meet growing regulatory requirements.

We continue to develop our climate scenario analysis exercises to have a more comprehensive understanding of climate headwinds, risks, and opportunities that will support our strategic planning and actions. We do not currently fully disclose the impacts of climate-related issues on financial planning, particularly the impact on financial performance and financial position. We expect to further enhance our disclosure and processes in relation to acquisitions/divestments in the medium term.

Climate change poses a physical risk to the buildings we occupy as an organization, including offices, retail branches, and data centers. We use stress testing to evaluate the potential impact to our owned or leased premises. Our scenario stress test, conducted in 2022, analyzed how seven different climate change-related hazards could impact 500 of our critical and important buildings.

Our Climate Solutions Partnership is a philanthropic initiative that aims to identify and remove barriers to scale for climate change solutions. We support start-up companies developing carbon-cutting technologies, nature-based solutions, renewable energy initiatives in Asia, and the WWF-led Asia Sustainable Palm Oil Links programme.

During Board meetings, we balance discussions on the company's performance, emerging risks, and duties to shareholders while remaining conscious of responsibilities to support communities and help customers. In 2022, the Board approved an update to the thermal coal phase-out policy and the publication of an updated energy policy. We have committed to publishing our own climate transition plan in 2023. input:
