output:
Our initial approach to managing climate risk involved understanding the physical and transition impacts across five priority risk areas: wholesale credit risk, retail credit risk, reputational risk, resilience risk, and regulatory compliance risk. Process - We have integrated climate risk into our existing risk framework, and incorporated it into the policies and controls for the relevant risks where appropriate. We recognize the need for enhanced capabilities and new sources of data.

We consider greenwashing to be an emerging risk that is likely to increase over time, as we develop capabilities and offerings to help our clients transition to a low-carbon economy. We also acknowledge that green finance taxonomies are not consistent globally, and evolving taxonomies and practices could result in revisions in our sustainable finance reporting going forward.

We use stress testing and scenario analysis to assess how these climate risks will impact our customers, business, and infrastructure. Integration into policies and procedures - In 2022, we incorporated climate considerations into our mortgage origination process for our retail mortgage business and new money request process for our key wholesale businesses. We also continued to enhance our climate risk scoring tool, which will enable us to assess our customers’ exposures to climate risk. We published our updated energy policy, covering various sectors, and updated our thermal coal phase-out policy.

We are integrating climate risk into the policies, processes, and controls across many areas of our organization, and we will continue to update these as our climate risk management capabilities mature over time.

Consider climate-related risks in traditional banking industry risk categories (supplementary guidance for banks) - In 2022, we expanded our scope to consider climate risk impacts on our other risk areas (including treasury risk and traded risk) in our risk framework. We also analyzed in our internal scenario analysis exercise how climate risks impact how we manage other risks within our organization, including credit risk, and on an exploratory basis: market, operational, liquidity, insurance, and pension risks.

At our company, we take a proactive approach to managing climate risk and are committed to incorporating it into all aspects of our business. We recognize the importance of staying informed about the latest developments in climate risk and are continuously enhancing our capabilities to address these risks effectively.

Over the next three years, our company will work to enhance the management of climate risk across our organization. This will be a company-wide initiative with involvement from our asset owner and asset manager business units, risk, actuarial, and government relations teams.

Scenario analysis will be a key focus area as we plan to incorporate it into our mainstream risk management processes during 2021 and report findings within management information at the company and business unit levels. As we explore how climate risk impacts our business in the long term, we aim to operationalize and increase the use of scenario testing. We plan to voluntarily run scenario tests emerging from regulators, such as exploratory climate risk scenarios for financial institutions in 2021.

Many organizations have set targets in alignment with global climate goals. Our company is assessing similar targets in respect of the carbon emissions from our investments, given their significance within our overall emissions profile, and our commitment to decarbonizing our investment portfolio.

In the interim, we continue to increase our level of ambition in relation to our own emissions footprint. This year we have set new and stretching targets for our Scope 1 and Scope 2 greenhouse gas emissions, with the aim of becoming net carbon neutral across these two scopes by the end of 2030. More information on the environmental impact of our direct operations is available in the Environmental section on page 46.

During 2021, we will continue to scale up our engagement strategy with key policy and political stakeholders around major climate conferences, with a focus on financial sector issues to support the just transition and sustainable finance priorities, particularly in emerging markets. We also recognize that the implementation of our strategic ESG framework can generate opportunities for our company. Some of these opportunities will come through our efforts to take early mitigating action against the climate risks we identify, including incorporating transition risk into investment decisions to reduce the risk of being exposed to stranded assets. Others will come through supporting an inclusive transition. The infrastructure and capital expenditure required to enable the transition represents attractive investment opportunities in many cases. For example, there is a role for institutions to both develop new products and invest in structures and mechanisms that enable a managed withdrawal from reliance on coal-powered electricity within developing economies. In response to this, we have developed several responsible investment products that channel our customers’ savings towards ESG-themed investments, such as the Asia Sustainable Bond Fund recently launched by Eastspring. More information on our ESG-related investment activity is available in the Responsible Investment section on page 34.

output:
Our company's approach to setting targets for climate-related risks and opportunities:

We plan to begin this transition starting in 2030, with more aggressive targets for thermal coal emissions set for 2024. Our progress can be found in the Financed emission section.
• In terms of climate-related opportunities, we have set a $1 billion Sustainable Finance income target and a $300 billion mobilization of Sustainable Finance targets, with deadlines extending to 2025 and 2030, respectively.
• During the year, we updated the measurement of our Oil and gas sector emissions from income-based carbon intensity to absolute financed emissions. This modification was made to provide a more accurate representation of the sector's emission profile and establish a carbon budget intended to decrease over time.
• In 2022, we expanded the scope of our financed emissions calculations and, in this report, we announce three new sectoral targets covering transportation. By 2030, we aim to reduce emissions in the transportation sector:
  – A 34% reduction in aviation (production intensity)
  – Reduce our alignment delta in shipping from +2.6% to 0%
  – A 49% reduction in automotive manufacturers (production intensity)
Description of methodologies used to calculate targets and measures:
• The methodologies used to calculate baseline emissions are detailed in the Our Financed Emissions section.
Other key performance indicators used:
• In 2021, we introduced Sustainability Aspirations, which include an interim target to aim for net zero in our operations by 2025 and in our financed emissions by 2050. In 2022, we advanced our target for reaching net zero in our operations by 2025 to 2023.

input: 1. Outline how the Board monitors and manages climate-related risks and opportunities.
output:
Our company's Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) initiatives are overseen by the Board, which determines strategy and priority areas. The Board recognizes the importance of the next 12 to 18 months for the implementation of our ESG Strategic Framework and related matters, such as our purpose and values, diversity and inclusion priorities, and employee engagement activities.

We have established a Group ESG Committee to provide senior executive involvement and holistic oversight of ESG matters. The Committee is chaired by our CFO and COO and includes our Chief Risk and Compliance Officer, HR Director, and senior representatives from our business units. One responsibility of the Group ESG Committee is to oversee our progress towards reporting against the recommendations of the Financial Stability Board's Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures (TCFD).

Our policies and procedures for managing ESG issues are outlined in our Company Governance Manual (CGM). The CGM is subject to annual review and sets standards for managing potential ESG issues across the organization. Any instances of non-compliance with the CGM identified through annual attestations are assessed by policy owners and reported to the Audit Committee.

We believe that our new strategic ESG framework and long-term goals to decarbonize our investment portfolio and support an inclusive transition are essential for meeting stakeholder expectations and fulfilling our fiduciary obligations. This approach will reduce our exposure to asset risk, including transition risk, over time, while also contributing to global decarbonization efforts.

Our Risk function conducted an initial transition risk analysis on insurance assets managed in segregated portfolios by our asset managers. This analysis focused on investments where we maintain direct control and exert influence over the investment process. Preliminary reports were generated using climate-related data and metrics provided through a proprietary vendor tool. This analysis facilitates a breakdown of the contributions of different sectors to our overall carbon footprint metrics and highlights the most carbon-intensive sectors and companies.

Our Board's oversight of climate change risk has been significantly strengthened. ESG matters, including climate change, are now overseen by a Responsibility & Sustainability Working Group, which ensures appropriate Board engagement and oversight until May 2022. A Board Risk Committee workshop was held to evaluate the climate change risks facing the company, discuss transition and physical risk concepts, and review potential Key Risk Indicators (KRIs).

instruction: Using your extensive knowledge of the TCFD (Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures) framework, create in-depth reports for financial institutions outlining the steps they should take to integrate climate-related risks into their risk management systems. input: 1. Enterprise risk management process
output:
Our company has established and overseen a collection of risk management and control mechanisms to identify developments that may threaten our business continuity. Central components of these mechanisms include enterprise-wide procedures for strategic planning and management reporting. Strategic planning enables us to recognize potential risks prior to significant business decisions, while management reporting facilitates closer monitoring of risks as our business advances. Our internal auditors regularly evaluate the sufficiency and efficiency of our risk management, and any shortcomings can be remedied through suitable measures.

Our risk management strategy is all-encompassing, dynamic, and management-focused, and is embedded within our organization. It encompasses both risks and opportunities. Our strategy adheres to globally recognized standards, such as the COSO Standard and ISO 31000, and is customized to our company's specifications. The frameworks link our risk management process with our financial reporting process and internal control system.

Our risk management process aims for early recognition and evaluation of risks and opportunities that could materially impact our strategic, operational, financial, and compliance objectives. The timeframe is generally three years, and we employ a net risk approach, addressing risks and opportunities that remain following the implementation of existing control measures. Relevant risks and opportunities are identified in a systematic manner, combining elements of both top-down and bottom-up approaches. Reporting typically follows a quarterly cycle, with an ad-hoc reporting process to escalate critical issues promptly.

Relevant risks and opportunities are prioritized based on impact and probability, taking into account various viewpoints, including business objectives, reputation, and regulatory requirements. The bottom-up identification and prioritization process is supplemented by workshops with the respective management of our organizational units. The top-down component ensures that potential new risks and opportunities are discussed at various management levels and are incorporated into the subsequent reporting process, if deemed relevant.

Reported risks and opportunities are assessed for potential cumulative effects and are consolidated within and for each of the departments mentioned. Responsibilities are assigned for all relevant risks and opportunities, with the level of responsibility depending on the significance of the respective risk or opportunity. Our response strategies include avoidance, transfer, reduction, acceptance, and capitalizing on opportunities. For each risk or opportunity, responsibility entails the development, initiation, and monitoring of suitable response measures corresponding to the chosen response strategy. These response measures are specifically designed to facilitate effective risk management.

Our company manages various risks, including those related to economic conditions and customer demand, project risks, and risks from the transmission of infectious agents. We closely monitor macroeconomic trends and developments in relevant industries to address the risk of economic instability and fluctuating customer demand. We maintain adequate insurance coverage for potential damage and liability risks to minimize our exposure and mitigate potential losses. We continually gather information from relevant sources to identify epidemic or pandemic risks and related countermeasures as early as possible.

The analysis did not influence our strategy but strongly confirmed it. The results revealed that our portfolio is resilient to climate change. instruction: You have been assigned the role of a Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) strategist.
input:
Answer the following questions: 
1. Handling climate-related risk and opportunities
output:
Our company does not see any significant transitional or physical risks from climate change that have a material impact on us, but rather view the transition toward a low carbon economy as an opportunity. Climate change and its mitigation are significant issues for our stakeholders. We enable our customers to lower their greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions by providing low carbon and energy-efficient products, solutions, and services. Our Environmental Portfolio (EP) helps our customers to mitigate their CO2 footprint, reduce energy costs, and improve profitability through higher productivity. In fiscal year 2020, we managed to reduce 150 million metric tons of CO2 at customer sites. Our business SI, for example, has been established with a priority focus on decentralization, decarbonization, and energy efficiency in buildings and cities. SI strategy addresses the ongoing challenges and seizes the opportunities of new technologies around the grid edge with products and solutions for decentralized energy systems, photovoltaic inverters, energy storage, smart and sustainable buildings, and electro mobility, enabled by digitalization. For instance, we have been guaranteeing energy performance contracts since 1995 and have to date enabled our customers to save 13 million tons of CO2.

Regarding our own operations, we are committed to becoming carbon neutral by 2030. This year, we managed to halve our emissions compared to 2014. Among other benefits, this program reduces potential carbon taxational risk on our operations. Through our dedicated decarbonization program within the supply chain, we also reduce this risk upstream.

With respect to potential physical risks, we continuously evaluate and monitor changes in climate parameters based on global studies, weather statistics, and trends based on international experience of insurance companies. We do not consider those risks to lead to substantive changes in operations, revenue, or expense as they allow for mitigation. In addition, we perform local risk assessments and develop protection concepts if needed. Furthermore, our insurance department provides natural hazard risks analysis for each new building project that drives the selection process for new site areas and influences technical, organizational, and physical protection measures.

The collected data and information allow us to identify geographical areas where we pay special attention at our sites in terms of risks from changes to physical climate parameters. For example, at one of our sites, we installed flood protection measures in 2013 as a preventative measure. This measure was put to the test in 2018 and proved effective, as our site was not impacted despite heavy floods within the area. In 2020, we further enhanced our processes for physical risk assessment, as we are faced with a more competitive insurance market with less overall insurer capacity most likely driven by increasing overall impacts of natural disasters.

Jointly with our insurer and our risk management partner, we evaluate 80% of our insured value with respect to fire safety but also natural catastrophes, such as storms, floods, hurricanes, on a yearly basis. The analysis revealed that major sites were exposed. We see flood risks mainly in Europe, whereas some sites in other countries are exposed to storms or hurricanes. For these identified sites, a more detailed risk analysis was performed, and results were provided to our insurer to adjust payment conditions. In addition, and in alignment with our overall EHS emergency response management system, we provided measures to be taken by the identified sites, such as installation of flood barriers, thickening of roofs. The requirements for risk mitigation measures are continuously enhanced and consider risk changes.

This process is complementary to the implementation of our water strategy. Based on our global binding EHS regulation, every environmentally relevant site must perform a risk assessment. This includes the evaluation of water-related climate change risks, such as their water stress level, exposure to flooding, droughts, and general water availability. For this assessment, we use Aqueduct (WRI) and IPCC data to predict changes in precipitation. This assessment is verified by our internal tool with each site responsible for performing a bottom-up analysis. In fiscal year 2020, we had analyzed 97% of locations.

One example for an acute physical risk could be from drought in water-stressed areas. One of our sites in a water-stressed country has established a comprehensive water management system with active collection of rainwater during the rainy season, which is fed back into the ground to increase necessary groundwater levels during the dry season instead of letting it run off through sewers. In addition, the site benefits, as it is more independent from the public water supply.

Natural disasters could potentially interrupt our supply chain. However, supply chain risks are low, due to our diversified supplier base, worldwide operations, and a limited number of our facilities concentrated in any particular region, including those regions more likely to be affected by natural disasters. Nevertheless, we analyze potential supply chain disruptions both within our supplier selection and qualification process as well as in the phase of continuous supply chain operations. Based on external real-time data from service provider risk methods, which indicates risk alerts in any region worldwide, our businesses are mitigating upcoming supply chain risks to ensure flawless deliveries to our customers. Due to proven risk indicators such as natural disasters, COVID-19-related lockdown areas, and financial alert data, which will be supported through AI-driven data analytics, we preventively managed several risk cases (e.g., COVID-19, natural disasters) to ensure the resilience of our supply chain during major crises.

instruction: In your role as a TCFD expert, you will be detailing the optimal approaches for conducting climate risk evaluations.
input:
Answer the following questions: 
1. Addressing and leveraging climate-related risks and opportunities
output:
Our company does not see any substantial transitional or physical risks from climate change that have a material impact on us, but rather view the transition toward a low carbon economy as an opportunity. Climate change and its mitigation are significant issues for our stakeholders. We enable our customers to lower their greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions by providing low carbon and energy-efficient products, solutions, and services. Our Environmental Portfolio (EP) helps our customers to mitigate their CO2 footprint, reduce energy costs, and improve profitability through higher productivity. In fiscal year 2020, we managed to reduce 150 million metric tons of CO2 at customer sites. Our Business Services (SI) division, for instance, has been established with a priority focus on decentralization, decarbonization, and energy efficiency in buildings and cities. SI strategy addresses the ongoing challenges and seizes the opportunities of new technologies around the grid edge with products and solutions for decentralized energy systems, photovoltaic inverters, energy storage, smart and sustainable buildings, and electro mobility, enabled by digitalization. For example, we have been providing energy performance contracts since 1995 and have helped our customers save 13 million tons of CO2.

Regarding our own operations, we are committed to becoming carbon neutral by 2030. This year, we managed to reduce our emissions by half compared to 2014. This program not only reduces potential carbon taxational risk on our operations but also upstream through our dedicated decarbonization program within the supply chain.

With respect to potential physical risks, we continuously evaluate and monitor changes in climate parameters based on global studies, weather statistics, and trends based on international experience of insurance companies. We do not consider those risks to lead to substantive changes in operations, revenue, or expense as they allow for mitigation. In addition, we perform local risk assessments and develop protection concepts if needed. Furthermore, our insurance department provides natural hazard risks analysis for each new building project that drives the selection process for new site areas and influences technical, organizational, and physical protection measures. The collected data and information allow us to identify geographical areas where we pay special attention at our sites in terms of risks from changes to physical climate parameters. For example, at one of our sites, we installed flood protection measures in 2013 as a preventative measure. This measure was put to the test in 2018 and proved effective, as our site was not impacted despite heavy floods within the area. In 2020, we further enhanced our processes for physical risk assessment, as we are faced with a more competitive insurance market with less overall insurer capacity most likely driven by increasing overall impacts of natural disasters.

Jointly with our insurer and our risk management partner, we evaluate on a yearly basis 80% of our insured value with respect to fire safety but also natural catastrophes, such as storms, floods, hurricanes. The analysis was based on RMS (Risk Management Solution) data. This analysis revealed that major sites were exposed. We see flood risks mainly in Europe, whereas some sites in the US, Philippines, or Japan are exposed to storms or hurricanes. For these identified sites, a more detailed risk analysis was performed, and results were provided to our insurer to adjust payment conditions. In addition, and in alignment with our overall EHS emergency response management system, we provided measures to be taken by the identified sites, such as installation of flood barriers, thickening of roofs. The requirements for risk mitigation measures are continuously enhanced and consider risk changes.

This process is complementary to the implementation of our company's Water Strategy. Based on our global binding EHS regulation, every environmentally relevant site must perform a risk assessment. This includes the evaluation of water-related climate change risks, such as their water stress level, exposure to flooding, droughts, and general water availability. For this assessment, we use Aqueduct (WRI) and IPCC data to predict changes in precipitation. This assessment is verified by our company's internal tool with each site responsible for performing a bottom-up analysis. In fiscal year 2020, we had analyzed 97% of locations.

One example for an acute physical risk could be from drought in water-stressed areas. One of our sites in India has established a comprehensive water management system with active collection of rainwater during the monsoon, which is fed back into the ground to increase necessary groundwater levels during the dry season instead of letting it run off through sewers. In addition, the site benefits as it is more independent from the public water supply.

In addition to our own operations, natural disasters could potentially interrupt our supply chain. However, supply chain risks are low due to our diversified supplier base, worldwide operations, and a limited number of our company's facilities concentrated in any particular region, including those regions more likely to be affected by natural disasters. Nevertheless, we analyze potential supply chain disruptions both within our supplier selection and qualification process as well as in the phase of continuous supply chain operations. Based on external real-time data from service provider risk methods, which indicates risk alerts in any region worldwide, our businesses are mitigating upcoming supply chain risks to ensure flawless deliveries to our customers. Due to proven risk indicators such as natural disasters, COVID-19-related lockdown areas, and financial alert data, which will be supported through AI-driven data analytics, we preventively managed several risk cases (e.g., COVID-19, natural disasters) to ensure the resilience of our supply chain during major crises.

output:
At our company, we integrate the management of climate-related risks into our Enterprise Risk Management (ERM) system. Our ERM approach is grounded in globally recognized standards, such as the COSO Standard "Enterprise Risk Management – Integrating with Strategy and Performance" (2017) and the ISO Standard 31000 (2018). These frameworks are customized to fit our unique needs.

Our ERM process is interconnected with our financial reporting process and our internal control system. The strategic direction of the company, the productivity and efficiency of its operations, the accuracy of its financial reporting, and adherence to applicable laws and regulations are all given equal importance. ERM employs a net risk approach, addressing risks and opportunities that persist following the implementation of existing risk mitigation measures. Relevant risks and opportunities are ranked based on their potential impact and probability.

Responsibilities are delegated for all material risks and opportunities, with the extent of responsibility contingent on the significance of the respective risk or opportunity. The timeframe typically spans three years, but our ERM system also encompasses a long-term forward-looking component to monitor emerging risks and opportunities beyond three years, up to a century. Evaluation is predicated on the magnitude and pace of the risks and opportunities.

input: 1.  Integration of climate risk into the risk management framework
output:
Our approach to managing risks and opportunities related to climate change is integrated into our Enterprise Risk Management (ERM) framework. The evaluation of climate risks and opportunities is incorporated into our top-down and bottom-up processes, providing a comprehensive overview of our business activities. In fiscal 2020, the criteria for this climate change related top-down approach were specified in more detail based on the TCFD recommendations and are available to all business units as part of their quarterly risk management discussions.

Climate change is not a standalone category within ERM, but is rather considered within the risk identification of the four areas: strategic, operational, financial, and compliance-related risks. In order to evaluate the potential climate change related net-risk for our ERM reporting, pre-ERM processes are in place. These include, for example, our environmental management system with its corresponding risk assessment of environmental impacts from our production or products.

The disclosure of risks is respectively bundled within the above-mentioned four areas and outlined in our Annual Report. Regarding climate change, we see respective measures that need to be taken as business opportunities.

By enabling our customers to lower their Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions across our portfolio and by reducing CO2 emissions in our own operations, our company aims to support the trend towards a low-carbon economy. Recent legislative and governmental initiatives to mitigate climate change worldwide, especially in Europe through initiatives such as the Green Deal or Sustainable Finance, present opportunities for our company.

instruction: In your role as a TCFD (Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures) professional, you will be detailing the optimal approaches for conducting climate risk assessments.
input:
Answer the following questions: 
1. Describe the resilience of the organization’s strategy, taking into consideration different climate-related scenarios, including a 2°C or lower scenario.
output:
Our company's scenario analysis as per the TCFD Recommendations reveals that our carbon-related credit exposure (EXP) represents 7.3% of our total credit exposure. Our transition risk assessment concentrates on the electric utilities and oil, gas & coal sectors in Japan. The analysis timeframe spans until 2050, although the International Energy Agency (IEA) scenario concludes in 2040. The estimated cost increases under dynamic and static scenarios are ¥120 billion and ¥310 billion, respectively. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) Representative Concentration Pathway (RCP) scenarios we considered are 8.5 (4°C) and 2.6 (2°C).

In evaluating potential implications for our clients' businesses, we applied two scenarios: a static one, assuming no business transformation, and a dynamic one, involving business structure adaptation. Our analysis primarily focused on credit costs through 2050.

We utilized a Monte Carlo simulation to ascertain the rates at which typhoons and other storms result in wind and water-related building loss or damage. Subsequently, we analyzed the potential direct (collateral value) and indirect (business stagnation) impacts on our company's credit costs from the loss or damage of mortgaged real estate (buildings) in Japan. This analysis targeted middle-market firms and SMEs in Japan. The impact on mortgage lending value was minimal, while the impact of business stagnation was ¥52 billion at most under both 2°C and 4°C scenarios.

input: 1. Detail the Board's supervision of risks and opportunities related to climate.
output:
Our company's Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) initiatives are overseen by the Board, which determines strategy and priority areas. In 2020, a Group ESG Committee was established to provide senior executive involvement and holistic oversight of ESG matters material to our organization. The Committee is chaired by the Chief Financial Officer and Chief Operening Officer, and includes the Chief Risk and Compliance Officer, the HR Director, and senior representatives from our business units. One of the Group ESG Committee's responsibilities is to oversee our progress towards fulfilling our commitment to report against the recommendations of the Financial Stability Board’s Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures (TCFD). In 2020, the Group ESG Committee reported to the Board through the Nomination & Governance Committee.

The Board recognizes that the next 12 to 18 months are critical for the implementation of our ESG Strategic Framework. Therefore, in early 2021, a Responsibility & Sustainability Working Group was established to ensure appropriate Board engagement and oversight during this period. The Working Group is chaired by a Non-executive Director and comprises four other Non-executive Directors.

Our company's policies and procedures for managing Environmental, Social, and Governance issues are outlined in our Group Governance Manual. This manual is subject to an annual content review, taking into consideration both internal and external factors. Any instances of non-compliance with the manual identified by our businesses through their annual attestation are assessed by the policy owners and reported to the Group Audit Committee.

We believe that our new strategic ESG framework and long-term goals to reduce our carbon footprint and support an inclusive transition are essential for meeting stakeholder expectations and fulfilling our fiduciary obligations. This approach will help us reduce our exposure to asset risk over time while contributing to global decarbonization efforts. Our Risk function conducted an initial transition risk analysis on insurance assets managed in segregated portfolios by our asset managers. This analysis focused on investments where we maintain direct control and exert influence over the investment process. Preliminary reports were produced using climate-related data and metrics provided through a proprietary vendor tool. This facilitates a breakdown of the contributions of different sectors to our overall carbon footprint metrics and highlights the most carbon-intensive sectors, including those most at risk of being stranded. It also enables us to determine and monitor the most carbon-intensive companies held in our asset book. We have also determined the initial weighted average carbon intensity (WACI) of the listed equity and corporate bond asset classes of our insurance investment portfolio.

The Board's oversight of climate change risk has been significantly strengthened. In 2020, ESG was overseen by the Board through the Nomination & Governance Committee. In early 2021, a Responsibility & Sustainability Working Group was established until May 2022 to ensure appropriate Board engagement and oversight of ESG matters (including climate change). A Board Risk Committee workshop was held to evaluate the climate change risks facing our organization, discuss transition and physical risk concepts, and review potential Key Risk Indicators (KRIs).

instruction: As a TCFD consultant, your responsibilities include providing specific recommendations for enhancing metrics and establishing new targets in the area of climate-related financial risk disclosures.
input:

 Describe the organization’s processes for managing climaterelated risks 
 Elaborate on the incorporation of the company's procedures for pinpointing, evaluating, and handling climate-related risks into its comprehensive risk management strategy.
output:
Our company's Direct Operations:
Risk management is a crucial process in our organization, encompassing all functions. We identify risks related to financial and market performance, operational efficiency, emergency preparedness and response, environmental compliance, and health and safety. We evaluate risks based on their potential impact on our business, employees, communities, and customers, as well as regulatory requirements. Our Enterprise Risk Management program identifies, assesses, prioritizes, and manages key enterprise risks, including climate-related risks and opportunities.
Our Finance, Internal Audit, Legal, and Investor Relations departments evaluate domestic and international business risks, financial risks, market risks, and environmental compliance risks. These risks are reviewed as part of financial disclosure requirements. In addition, departments such as Environment, Health and Safety, Corporate Sales and Marketing, Legal, Operations, and Investor Relations assess specific physical and transitional risks and opportunities due to climate change. We have reviewed potential physical climate change risks to major facilities, including sea level rise flooding, susceptibility to and preparation for high intensity storms, increased rainfall, drought, and water stress and availability. We have considered raw material sourcing issues and distribution channel impacts that could result from global climate-related impacts. We use a $1 million USD threshold to determine potential impacts due to climate change.
Our company uses a materiality assessment to review and prioritize sustainability topics, including corporate governance, products, environmental protection (including climate change), social responsibility, and economic performance. Our top management discusses which aspects are most relevant for our company's future success. We also consult external stakeholders, such as customers and suppliers, to understand their perspectives. The results from the materiality assessment guide us in focusing on specific areas. Our Environment, Health & Safety department is responsible for maintaining our ISO 14001 certifications. Our ISO 14001 environmental management systems involve assessing environmental impacts of our manufacturing operations, including those impacted by climate change. ISO 14001 defines an environmental aspect as an element of an organization's activities, products, or services that has or may have an impact on the environment. Our significant impacts for each site covered under an ISO 14001 certification are determined using a ranking system. Each environmental aspect, such as greenhouse gas emissions and energy usage, is ranked from 0 through 4 based on criteria like severity, magnitude, probability, frequency, controllability, duration, employee concerns, community concerns, boundaries, business impact, and regulatory. The highest scores identify our significant impacts, which we focus on in more detail in our environmental management systems.
We have established corporate-wide goals to manage climate-related risks. Our sustainability goals include a climate change-related target of reducing scope 1 and 2 emissions by 50% by 2030 relative to a base year. We also have a long-term goal of reducing scope 1 and 2 emissions in line with global climate targets to further reduce our climate impact and support limiting warming to 1.5°C and transitioning to a net-zero carbon economy.
Upstream:
During our climate-related risk assessments, we consider the impact climate change could have on our suppliers of raw materials. As a global organization, we rely on various suppliers for raw materials, some of which may be subject to supply constraints due to climate change. In instances where we depend on a limited number of suppliers for certain raw materials, components, services, and equipment used in the production of our products, climate change-related risks could affect us. For example, chronic drought or flooding could increase instability in regions that supply critical raw materials, causing business interruptions. We use a $1 million USD threshold to determine potential impacts due to climate change.
We assess upstream risks by calculating our upstream scope 3 GHG emissions, which helps us better understand our impact. Our Procurement department manages physical and transitional risks and opportunities in our supply chain. Our dedicated staff, Supplier Code of Conduct, Purchase Order Terms and Conditions, and Responsible Sourcing Policy help us manage potential supply chain risks, including those associated with climate change. Where possible, we seek to obtain goods and services from local suppliers in the locations where we conduct business, which helps reduce our risk of business interruptions when climate-related issues may arise and lowers transportation emission impacts.
Downstream:
During our climate-related risk assessments, we consider the impact climate change could have on our business downstream. We believe climate change presents a potential opportunity for us because our products are specifically designed to reduce energy consumption and GHG emissions compared to incumbent technologies. However, climate-related events could cause delays in product distribution, resulting in commercial risks associated with delivering our products in a timely manner. We use a $1 million USD threshold to determine potential impacts due to climate change.
We assess downstream risks by calculating our downstream scope 3 GHG emissions, which helps us better understand our impact. Our Corporate Sales and Marketing department manages our climate-related transitional risks and opportunities, including those related to our product sales, reputation, market projections, and consumer preferences. We assess market trends and technology advancements to suggest what our business focus should be. For example, we have shifted our strategic focus toward certain business areas due to the anticipated increased adoption of energy-efficient technologies that use our products (e.g., renewable energy, electric vehicles).

input: 1. Describe the potential impact of different scenarios, including a 2°C scenario, on the organisation's businesses, strategy, and financial planning.
output:
Over the next three years, our company will work to enhance the management of climate risk throughout our organization. This will be a company-wide, cross-functional initiative involving participation from our asset owner and asset manager business units, risk, actuarial, and government relations teams.

Scenario analysis will be a key focus area as we plan to incorporate it into our mainstream risk management processes during 2021 and begin reporting findings within management information at the company and business unit levels. As we continue to examine how climate risk affects our business in the long term, we aim to implement and expand the use of scenario testing. We plan to voluntarily run scenario tests emerging from regulators, such as exploratory climate risk scenarios for financial institutions in 2021.

Many organizations have established targets in alignment with global climate goals. Our company is in the process of evaluating similar targets regarding the carbon emissions from our investments, given their significance within our overall emissions profile, and our commitment to decarbonizing our investment portfolio.

In the interim, we continue to raise the bar in relation to our own emissions footprint. This year we have set new and challenging targets for our Scope 1 and Scope 2 greenhouse gas emissions, with the goal of achieving net carbon neutrality across these two scopes by the end of 2030. More information on the environmental impact of our direct operations can be found in the Environmental section on page 46.

During 2021, we will continue to intensify our engagement strategy with key policy and political stakeholders around major climate conferences, with a focus on financial sector issues to support the just transition and sustainable finance priorities, particularly in emerging markets. We also recognize that the implementation of our strategic ESG framework can generate opportunities for our company. Some of these opportunities will come through our efforts to take early mitigating action against the climate risks we identify, including incorporating transition risk into investment decisions to reduce the risk of being exposed to stranded assets. Others will come through supporting an inclusive transition. The infrastructure and capital expenditure required to enable the transition presents attractive investment opportunities in many cases. For example, there is a role for institutions to both develop new products and invest in structures and mechanisms that facilitate a managed withdrawal from reliance on coal-powered electricity within developing economies. In response to this, we have developed several responsible investment products that channel our customers’ savings towards ESG-themed investments, such as the Asia Sustainable Bond Fund recently launched by [Company Name]. More information on our ESG-related investment activity can be found in the Responsible Investment section on page 34.

A review is underway to establish suitable targets in respect of the carbon emissions from our investment portfolio. We are also exploring further environmental/climate risk opportunities, such as the development of investment, insurance and digital products to support climate risk management.

Approach to scenario analysis:
Over recent years, we have progressively strengthened our scenario analysis capabilities and developed our infrastructure and capabilities to incorporate Climate Risk into data, modelling, and analysis. Our company's work to date, using current assumptions and proxies, indicates that our business is resilient to all scenarios explored by the Network of Central Banks and Supervisors for Greening the Financial System (NGFS) and International Energy Agency (IEA).
In 2021, our company recognized Sustainability as a core component of our strategy, elevating it to a pillar of our Group Strategy. In July 2022, we formalised this further and appointed our inaugural Chief Sustainability Officer (CSO), to help drive our sustainability agenda and bring together our existing Sustainable Finance, Sustainability Strategy, and Net Zero Programme Management, teams.
Scenarios used:
In 2022, our company engaged a third-party vendor to begin development of bespoke internal modelling capabilities to provide greater transparency. We assessed the impact on our corporate client portfolio based on three IEA scenarios and three Phase 2 scenarios from the NGFS. We also assessed the impact of sea-level rises under various Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) Representative Concentration Pathways (RCP) scenarios to explore the Physical Risk impact on our residential mortgage portfolio over short and long-term time horizons for internal risk management purposes.
Impact of climate-related risks and opportunities on business strategy:

instruction: Prepare a comprehensive critique and enhancement plan, drawing on your knowledge of the TCFD framework, to assess and enhance an organization's existing practices for managing climate-related information. input:
Answer the following questions: 
1. Describe the organization’s processes for identifying and assessing climate-related risks.
output:
Processes for identifying and assessing risk:
To support the management and monitoring of Physical and Transition risks, our company continues to conduct case-level reviews for enhanced due diligence on high risks for our corporate clients. The toolkits are used to identify and assess:
- Physical Risk: current-day and longer-term time horizons (representative concentration pathway (RCP) scenarios 2.6, 4.5 and 8.5), for acute weather events (e.g. storms, floods or earthquakes) and chronic sea-level rise.
- Transition Risk: translates Orderly, Disorderly and ‘Hot-House’ world transition scenario variables from relevant sources to financial impact at a client level.

Further information on client-level assessments can be found on a generic page, and the limitations of our methodology can be found on a different generic page.

We define Climate Risk as the potential for financial loss and non-financial detriments arising from climate change and society’s response to it. Within this, we assess and define sub-risk types in the form of a climate risk taxonomy which includes:
- Physical Risk: Risk arising from increasing severity and frequency of climate and weather-related events.
- Transition Risk: Risks arising from the adjustment towards a carbon-neutral economy, which will require significant structural changes to the economy.

Existing and emerging regulatory requirements related to climate change:
Our company has established a process for tracking various Climate Risk-related regulatory developments and obligations set by both financial and non-financial service regulators at our organization and regional/country level. Roles and responsibilities are set out in our Climate Risk Policy. Regulatory requirements or enhancements needed are recorded through workplans across various teams. The workplans are coordinated and monitored through various working groups by having the relevant accountable executives participate in the relevant forums.

Characterising climate-related risks in the context of traditional banking industry risk categories:
Our company has identified seven Principal Risk Types (PRT) that are most materially impacted by potential climate risks and describe transmission channels for Climate Risk manifesting as financial and non-financial risk.

instruction: Your role: The TCFD (Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures) authority.
input: 1. Exploration of climate-related scenarios
output:
Our company positions ourselves as a leading partner in the decarbonization process for our customers and society. Decarbonization is expected to bring about significant changes to the energy value chain in the coming decades. We are committed to offering innovative technologies to facilitate this transition. This requires a deep understanding of the technological advancements and costs needed over the next 30 + years. To accomplish this, we have developed comprehensive multi-modal simulation tools. We have compared the outcomes of these tools with external research studies, such as IRENA, Fraunhofer, IHS, Agora Energiewende, and IEA.
Regarding our own operations, we have conducted scenario analysis as a stress test on our carbon neutral program to ensure its resilience to higher energy or CO2 prices. Our experts applied high-price scenarios using IHS Autonomy, IEA Sustainable Development Scenario, and the Greenpeace Energy Revolution scenario to identify potential risks to our CO2-reduction plan. By utilizing predictions on energy prices from these scenarios and a forecast for CO2 prices from a High-Level Commission on Carbon-Pricing, we evaluated necessary adjustments. The results of the analysis demonstrated that our existing program is sufficiently resilient.
Climate-related scenario analysis enables our business to anticipate potential consequences from regulatory changes, R&D, and customer trends and requirements. In fiscal 2020, we performed forward-looking scenario analysis in accordance with the TCFD recommendation. In addition to IHS scenarios, we applied the IEA SDS scenarios, focusing on indicators such as renewable uptake, decentralization, energy efficiency demand, and CO2 prices for 2020-2040. The analysis did not influence our strategy but strongly confirmed it. The results revealed that our portfolio is resilient to climate change. In fact, the majority of our portfolio benefits from energy transformation, including Virtual Power Plants (VPP), Decentralized Energy Systems (DES), future grids, Digital Grids, and storage, even more so in the next decades.
